title-group.article-title: Associations between the angiotensin-converting enzyme insertion/deletion polymorphism and susceptibility to vasculitis: a meta-analysis

contrib-group.aff: Division of Rheumatology, Department of Internal Medicine, Korea University College of Medicine, Seoul, Korea

author-notes.corresp: Young Ho Lee, Division of Rheumatology, Department of Internal Medicine, Korea University Anam Hospital, Korea University College of Medicine, 126-1, Anam-dong 5-ga, Seongbuk-gu, Seoul 136-705, Korea. Email: lyhcgh@korea.ac.kr

abstract.p: Introduction: To explore whether the insertion (I) and deletion (D) polymorphism of angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) confers susceptibility to vasculitis.
Materials and methods: A meta-analysis was conducted on the associations between the ACE I/D polymorphism and vasculitis.

Results: Twelve studies, including four on Behçet’s disease (BD), four on Henoch–Schenlein purpura (HSP), three on Kawasaki disease (KD), and one on Wegener’s granulomatosis, were available for the meta-analysis. Meta-analysis showed that the DD + ID genotype was associated with susceptibility to vasculitis (odds ratio [OR] 1.468, 95% confidence interval [CI] 1.214–1.468, p = 7.4 × 10−5). The overall OR for the D allele was significantly increased in BD (OR 1.313, 95% CI 1.017–1.695). Meta-analysis of the DD+ID genotype, the DD genotype and the DD vs. II genotype showed marginal associations with BD, but meta-analysis of the D allele, and the DD+ID genotype showed significant associations with HSP (OR 1.446, 95% CI 1.021–2.049, p = 0.038; OR 1.881, 95% CI 1.385–2.595, p = 6.6 × 10−5). On the other hand, meta-analysis showed no association between KD and the ACE I/D polymorphism.
Conclusions: This meta-analysis shows that the ACE I/D polymorphism is associated with vasculitis susceptibility, especially in BD and HSP.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Vasculitis is a heterogeneous group of disorders characterized by inflammation and damage in blood vessels, leading to tissue or organ injury.1 Although the etiology of vasculitis is not fully understood, it has been suggested to occur given suitable interactions between a susceptible genetic background and environmental factors.

Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) activates angiotensin I into angiotensin II and inactivates bradykinin via the kallikrein–kininogen system.2 Angiotensin II is the main effector molecule of the renin–angiotensin system (RAS) and it is pleiotropic and a mediator of the development and progression of renal disease.3 Furthermore, angiotensin II is a potent pro-inflammatory modulator that augments and perpetuates immune responses.3 The ACE gene, located on chromosome 17q23, contains an insertion (I) /deletion (D) polymorphism within intron 16 that involves the presence or absence of a 287 bp repeat sequence.4 The DD genotype is associated with about 2-fold higher tissue and plasma concentrations of ACE than the II genotype,4 and thus it seems possible that the D allele could play a role in the pathogenesis of vasculitis.

The ACE I/D polymorphism has been studied in the context of vasculitis.5–16 However, published genetic association results for the ACE I/D polymorphism are controversial and inconclusive,5–16 which may be due to small sample sizes, low statistical power, and/or clinical heterogeneity. Therefore, in order to overcome the limitations of individual studies, resolve inconsistencies, and reduce the likelihood that random errors are responsible for false-positive or false-negative associations,17 we turned to meta-analysis. In the present study, we investigated whether the ACE I/D polymorphism contributes to vasculitis susceptibility using a meta-analysis approach.

sec.title: Identification of eligible studies and data extraction
sec.p: A literature search was conducted for studies that examined associations between the ACE I/D polymorphism and vasculitis. We utilized the MEDLINE citation index to identify articles in which the ACE I/D polymorphism was determined in vasculitis patients and controls (up to June 2011). In addition, all references mentioned in identified articles were reviewed to identify studies not indexed by MEDLINE. The following key words and subject terms were searched, ‘angiotensin-converting enzyme’, ’ACE’, and ‘vasculitis’, and the following information was extracted from each identified study: author, year of publication, ethnicity of the study population, demographics, numbers of cases and controls, and the frequencies of the genotypes and alleles of the ACE I/D polymorphism.

sec.title: Evaluation of publication bias and study quality
sec.p: Funnel plots are used to detect publication bias, but they require a range of studies of varying sizes and subjective judgments, and thus, we evaluated publication bias using Egger’s linear regression test,18 which measures funnel plot asymmetry on a natural logarithm scale of odds ratios (ORs). The chi-square test was used to determine if observed genotype frequencies in controls conformed to Hardy–Weinberg (H–W) expectations.

sec.title: Evaluation of statistical associations
sec.p: We performed meta-analyses using: (i) the allelic contrast (D vs. I), (ii) the recessive (DD vs. ID + II), (iii) the dominant (DD + ID vs. II), and (iv) the additive models (DD vs. II). Point estimates of risks, ORs, and 95% confidence intervals (CIs) were estimated for each study. In addition, within- and between-study variations and heterogeneities were assessed using Cochran’s Q-statistic. This heterogeneity test assesses the null hypothesis that all studies evaluated the same effect. The effect of heterogeneity was quantified using I2, which ranges between 0 and 100% and represents the proportion of between-study variability attributable to heterogeneity rather than chance.19 I2 values of 25%, 50%, and 75% were nominally assigned as low, moderate, and high estimates. The fixed effects model assumes that a genetic factor has a similar effect on vasculitis susceptibility across all studies investigated, and that observed variations among studies are caused by chance alone.20 The random effects model assumes that different studies show substantial diversity and assesses both within-study sampling error and between-study variance.21 When study groups are homogeneous, the two models are similar, but if this is not the case the random effects model usually provides wider CIs than the fixed effects model. The random effects model is best used in the presence of significant between-study heterogeneity.21 Statistical manipulations were undertaken using a Comprehensive Meta-Analysis computer program (Biosta, Englewood, NJ, USA). The power of each study was computed as the probability of detecting an association between the ACE polymorphism and vasculitis using a significance level of 0.05, assuming an OR of 1.5 (small effect size). Power analysis was performed using the statistical program G*Power (http://www.psycho.uni-duesseldorf.de/aap/projects/gpower).

sec.title: Studies included in the meta-analysis
sec.p: Twenty-four studies were identified by electronic and manual searches and 15 were selected for a full-text review based on title and abstract details.5–16,22–24 Three studies were excluded because they did not investigate healthy controls.22–24 Thus, 12 studies met the inclusion criteria.5–16 These studies comprised four on Behçet’s disease (BD), four on Henoch–Schenlein purpura (HSP), three on Kawasaki disease (KD), and one Wegener’s granulomatosis (WG). They consisted of six Asian, four Turkish, and two European studies, and in total, they included 1184 cases and 1464 controls. Selected details of the individual studies are summarized in Table 1. The statistical powers of these 12 studies ranged from 16.7% to 53.6%. None of the studies had a statistical power exceeding 80%.

caption.p: Details of the individual studies included in the meta-analysis

fn.p: HSP: Henoch–Schonlein purpura, BD: Behçet’s disease, KD: Kawasaki disease, WG: Wegener’s granulomatosis, OR: odds ratio, CI: confidence interval, HWE: Hardy–Weinberg equilibrium. * Power calculations assume α = 0.05, OR = 1.5.

sec.title: Meta-analysis of the association between the ACE I/D polymorphism and vasculitis
sec.p: Meta-analysis was performed on all vasculitis patients and on patients with BD, HSP, or KD. A summary of the meta-analysis findings of the relation between the ACE I/D polymorphism and vasculitis is provided in Table 1. Meta-analysis revealed a non-significant association between the D allele and vasculitis (OR 1.211, 95% CI 0.997–1.471, p = 0.053) (Table 2), and meta-analysis of the ACE I/D polymorphism showed that the DD + ID genotype (dominant effect) was associated with susceptibility to vasculitis (OR 1.468, 95% CI 1.214–1.468, p = 7.4 × 10−5) (Table 2, Figure 1).

caption.p: Meta-analysis of the association between the ACE I/D polymorphism and vasculitis

fn.p: ACE I/D: angiotensin-converting enzyme insertion and deletion, BD: Behçet’s disease, HSP: Henoch–Schonlein purpura, KD: Kawasaki disease, OR: odds ratio, CI: confidence interval, F: fixed effects model, R: random effects model.

caption.p: ORs and 95% CIs of individual studies and pooled data for the association between the DD + ID genotype of the ACE I/D polymorphism and vasculitis.

sec.title: Meta-analysis of the association between the ACE I/D polymorphism and BD, HSP and KD
sec.p: The overall OR for the D allele was significantly higher in BD (OR 1.313, 95% CI 1.017–1.695, p = 0.037) (Table 2, Figure 2). Meta-analysis of the DD+ID genotype, the DD genotype, and the DD vs. II genotype showed a marginal associations with BD (OR 1.428, 95% CI 0.929–2.219, p = 0.104; OR 1.371, 95% CI 0.940–2.000, p = 0.101; OR 1.624, 95% CI 0.979–2.693, p = 0.060, respectively) (Table 2). On the other hand, meta-analysis of the D allele and of the DD+ID genotype showed significant associations with HSP (OR 1.446, 95% CI 1.021–2.049, p = 0.038; OR 1.881, 95% CI 1.385–2.595, p = 6.6 × 10−5), whereas no such relation was found for the DD genotype or the DD vs. II genotype (Table 2, Figure 2). Meta-analysis of the D allele, the DD+ID genotype, the DD genotype, and the DD vs. II genotype showed no association between KD and the ACE I/D polymorphism (Table 2).

caption.p: ORs and 95% CI of individual studies and pooled data for the association between the D allele of the ACE I/D polymorphism and BD and HSP.

sec.title: Heterogeneity and publication bias
sec.p: The distributions of genotypes of the ACE I/D polymorphism in control groups were consistent with the H–W equilibrium in nine of the 12 studies. Deviation from the H–W equilibrium among controls suggests the possibility of bias during control selection or genotyping errors. When we excluded these three studies,7–9 overall results of D vs. I in vasculitis were substantially affected (OR 1.276, 95% CI 1.008–1.515, p = 0.041). Between-study heterogeneity was found during meta-analyses of vasculitis, HSP, and KD, but no evidence of heterogeneity was found for meta-analyses in BD (Table 2). Publication bias causes a disproportionate number of positive studies, and poses a problem for meta-analyses, but Egger’s regression test showed no evidence of publication bias in this meta-analysis of the ACE I/D polymorphism in any of the diseases studied (Egger’s regression test p-values >0.1).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: ACE is expressed in a wide range of tissues including those of the kidneys, heart, lungs, vascular endothelium, and testes. ACE plays an important role in RAS and angiotensin II conversion, increases vascular smooth muscle cell contraction, and affects smooth muscle proliferation, monocyte adhesion, platelet adhesion, and aggregation. Angiotensin II also acts as a potent pro-inflammatory modulator.3,25 The ACE I/D polymorphism is located in an intron of the ACE gene, and is in strong linkage disequilibrium with genetic factors that influence serum ACE levels.4 In fact, the ACE I/D polymorphism accounts for approximately one-half of the variance in ACE plasma levels in man. Furthermore, the polymorphism has been studied in several diseases, such as Alzheimer’s disease, myocardial infarction, cerebral infarct, hypertension, and diabetic nephropathy, and these studies also reported associations between susceptibilities to these diseases and the DD genotype and D allele.26–30

In this meta-analysis, we combined evidence on the associations between the ACE I/D polymorphism and susceptibility to BD, HSP, and KD. Furthermore, meta-analysis showed that the DD + ID genotype (dominant effect) of the ACE I/D polymorphism was associated with susceptibility to vasculitis (OR 1.468, 95% CI 1.214–1.468, p = 7.4 × 10−5). Stratification by disease type revealed a significant association between BD, HSP, and the ACE I/D polymorphism. Furthermore, the overall OR of the D allele was significantly higher in BD and HSP than in controls (OR 1.313, 95% CI 1.017–1.695, p = 0.037; OR 1.446, 95% CI 1.021–2.049, p = 0.038).

BD is a chronic inflammatory disease characterized by recurrent oral and genital ulcers, skin lesions, and uveitis.31 BD also affects all types and sizes of blood vessels, the joints, the central nervous system, the lungs, and the gastrointestinal system.32 Vasculitis and thrombosis are prominent features in BD and endothelial dysfunction is considered to play an important role in the pathogenesis of vasculitis in BD.31 HSP, the most common vasculitis of childhood, is a systemic vasculitis involving small vessels and affecting the skin, joints, gastrointestinal tract, and kidneys.33 Although the etiologies of BD and HSP remain unclear, it is believed that genetic and environmental factors play significant roles in their developments. RAS play an important role in the modulation of vascular tone, and ACE plays a key role in regulating RAS activity.3 Moreover, in view of the fact that the ACE I/D polymorphism accounts for approximately one-half of the variance in ACE plasma levels,4 it is likely that the ACE I/D polymorphism plays a role in susceptibility to vasculitis.

KD is a systemic vasculitis characterized by medium-sized arteries and coronary arthritis, and results in cardiac events, such as, ischemia and myocardial infarction.34 KD is differentiated from other vasculitis diseases based on clinical manifestations. In the present study, we found no association between KD and the ACE I/D polymorphism. We do not know exactly why the association results from KD and other vasculitis diseases were different. However, the difference may be due to small sample sizes or a different type of vasculitis. Relatively few studies were conducted on the association between KD and the ACE I/D polymorphism, and their results were heterogeneous. Further studies are required on this topic.

The present study has some limitations that should be considered. First, publication bias, heterogeneity, and confounding factors may have distorted the meta-analysis. Second, we were unable to perform ethnic-specific meta-analysis due to limited data. Thus, further studies are required to allow meta-analysis by ethnic group to clarify the role of the ACE I/D polymorphism in various ethnic populations. Third, the degree of vasculitis is very different in each disease and it was unclear how the degree of vasculitis was involved in each disease. It would have been interesting to have examined whether an association exists between the ACE I/D polymorphism and the activity or clinical features of vasculitides, but this was not possible in the present study due to limited data.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This meta-analysis of the association between the ACE I/D polymorphism and vasculitis, based on a total sample of 1184 vasculitis and 1464 controls, shows that the ACE I/D polymorphism is associated with vasculitis susceptibility, especially in BD and HSP. Accordingly, our findings support the notion that the ACE I/D polymorphism plays a role in the pathogenesis of vasculitides, such as, BD and HSP.

fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
